newsitem.title: FRANCE: Britain, France agree to work for landmine ban.
newsitem.headline: Britain, France agree to work for landmine ban.

text.p: Britain and France on Wednesday agreed a joint effort to ban anti-personnel landmines and said they hoped Germany would join the campaign.

"We hope we will be able today to make a tripartite statement comitting our three countries to work together to achieve a ban on the landmines that have caused so much suffering around the world," British Foreign Secretary Robin Cook told reporters after meeting French Foreign Minister Herve de Charette.

Cook, on his first foreign trip since taking office last week after his Labour Party ended 18 years of conservative rule, said he and de Charette had agreed a text on landmines and he would seek to have it endorsed later in the day by German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel.
Cook said he hoped that his trip to Paris and Bonn would mark the start of a new era in Britain's relations with Europe after what he called a sterile and fruitless period of confrontation.
He said that France and Beritain would try to work out a joint approach to a review of the workings of European Union institutions at the EU Intergovernmental Conference.
"Britain will of course insist on the protection of its vital national interests such as our anxiety to ensure we preserve our external border control against third countries," he added.
